author: R Sujatha
text:
The government’s proposal to improve its nurse base could significantly bring down the number of nurses appointed on contract. Currently, of the 10,000 nurses on contract, 3,500 have completed more than five years.

The qualified ‘merit candidate’ nurses are recruited on a consolidated pay of Rs. 7,700 and in rural areas an additional Rs. 500 is included. They receive a five per cent annual hike on their salary.

On Saturday afternoon, the Tamil Nadu Government Contract Nurses Welfare Association suspended its strike for 10 days after the Health Minister’s assurance that their demands would be addressed.

The government has promised placements through counselling within a week for 809 nurses, who have served more than six years, and within 10 days another 2,607 nurses with over five years’ service would be regularised.

Association president R. Marimuthu, however, said the government could accommodate all contract nurses by following the Medical Council of India norms.

In PHCs, the government must create at least six permanent posts, as contract nurses often work more than 12 hours.

“If in intensive care, critical care, cardiac care, neonatal and neuro intensive care units, the ratio of 1:1 patient to nurse is maintained quality care can be assured. The eight hours a nurse spends there ensures the patient is fed, cleaned, medicated and vital signs are monitored,” he said.

According to a health official, new schemes such as the rural health mission, communicable diseases project, neonatal intensive care and comprehensive emergency and obstetric care necessitated recruitment of nurses on contract.

But that anomaly was being set right steadily and the government had, in the past year, considerably reduced the ratio of nurse to contract nurse to 1:3.

With the government proposing to launch two new medical colleges in Pudukottai and Karur, 600 new nurse posts would be created.

The government is also sending a proposal to the Centre seeking higher salaries for nurses under the National Rural Health Mission, he said.

Government has promised to appoint over 3000 nurses through counselling
title: New proposal to increase nurse base, cut down contract staff
